6:57 I'm not a huge fan of how this is portrayed, it spreads the misconception that the speed of light is really some sort of traditional speed limit. As you increase your energy you keep going faster, a rocket pumping out fuel will always feel like its accelerate to an observer. As you get closer to lightspeed however, space around you will contract. While some relatively stable observer might see two stars be 1ly apart, if your close to the speed of light from your perspective (assuming you are parallel to the stars) they are closer together. You're not traveling faster than light, your going some percent of it but now there's basically less distance to travel. Now lightspeed is consistent across all observers, yes, so your perspective of a 5 minute journey over what used to be 1ly would be seen as over a year long trip to an observer on Earth.

Let's ask why the moon looks so big, bigger than a ring file hole. Biological adaptation is an obvious answer, maybe we have a piece of brain kit, a kind of internal telescope that kicks in at long distances as determined by visual angle. Useful not perhaps originally for space travel but maybe for resolving features on distant mountains, which explains why they too often look deceptively near.

Time lag due to spatial distortion can be observed as jerky or uneven motion in a two bladed wind turbine viewed from an angle instead of full on, when the blades appear to describe elliptical rather than circular motion. They therefore seem to slow down as they approach the vertices in order to compensate for the shorter distance they apparently cover there compared with the corresponding arc of the full circle, and speed up again as they approach the co-vertices. Go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q0wtu46iihw for a good example, but this effect is also visible in reality, not just on film or vid.

Speaking of hallucinations, that stuff is WILD. I'm 26, but a few years back, I'd hallucinate & see large spiders every once in a while - while I was awake. Initially I'd freak out & get away from them, but I could never find them again, and spiders that large don't really exist naturally where I live anyway.

As soon as I'd look back to where the spider was, it'd be gone. Eventually I managed to not freak out when I'd see one crawling or holding still wherever, & I'd just stare directly at it. There was no point at which it disappeared, but, gradually, it would become clear to me that there was no spider where I was looking. It was never there. I never saw it in the first place, so I never saw it go away.

The human brain is wild, man. And I'm a normal dude with no health complications - mental or physical. The whole situation has given me a little more respect for the legitimacy of mental conditions. Reality really is that concretely different to different people.

I think you just figured out why self-driving cars struggle so much with reality -- if they're perceiving the world at 1 frame per nanosecond (which I think is actually slower than they really do), then the images (individual pixels) from things mere feet away are lagging several frames behind where they really are. If you're not using neural nets which learn this fact on their own then that means you would have to manually program in a compensation for predicting where things further away actually are during any one frame of analysis. I guess that's why mixing 2D photos with 3D LIDAR scans gives a generally better picture of reality even though the laser is also lagging at the same rate the colors are, but at least there the travel time of light is intentionally used in the interpretation of the scan. Perhaps this is part of why we've evolved to perceive images as "slowly" as we do (where the average human can barely tell the difference between 60, 120, and 240 fps) because if we perceived things as quickly as robots could then we might struggle to make sense of anything a stone's throw away from us. This is all really mind-bending, but since you can't interact with anything faster than you can bounce photons off of it then maybe this lag doesn't make a practical difference in how robots interact with the world around them.... Charles Bonnet syndrome is super interesting and the first bit of this video reminded me of it. It happens with people who lost their vision, but were able to see prior to losing their vision. Their brains still try to take in the stimuli, so they make up an image. They may see glowing orbs, people having conversations, or whatever their brain makes up as it tries to figure out what it's looking at. These vivid hallucinations are often clearer than whatever the visually impaired person normally sees. Anyway, Google it for more in not a professional and I grossly oversimplified but ye

What I find more interesting than illusory effects is the way our brain can compensate for the errors allowing us to hit moving targets.  I recall an experiment in college where we had a pair of specially designed glasses with prisms that shifted the apparent position of everything you saw by about 3 feet to the right.  That means if you threw a football to the image you see, you would miss by 3 feet.  But, after about a dozen throws, your brain would adjust your muscle memory to compensate!  And then, if that wasn't trippy enough, when you took off the glasses you would then throw 3 feet to the left for a few throws until your brain readjusted your muscle memory again!  An experiment like this makes me wonder just how many of these "compensations" we experience on a daily basis!

What makes me curious though about the board in space theory is that in different mediums, sound travels at different speeds. For instance, sound can travel up to 7 times faster in steel than it can in water due to the collisions in the compression wave taking far less time to occur. So if the board was made from a material with a density so high that it takes zero time for the collisions to occur, would it instantly cause the wave to transfer energy to the other end no matter how long it is? Could our future generations use sound as a form of instant communication across our galaxy in the form of indestructible sound wires? I kinda doubt it since while sound travels faster and (I think) diffracts less in denser mediums, it also requires more energy to do so, therefore at incredibe densities, far more energy will be required to create a disturbance because the energy will be dispersed throught a much greater number of particles for the same amount of volume as the medium the energy was transferred through into the wire, also (idk if this next part is right), if a medium needs infinite density to create and instant reaction in a compression wave, then by the time we compressed a material dense enough, would it simply form a singularity, which occupies no space and therefore could not be used for a chain since it has no density? And unless we produced quite massive singularities, they would just decay and fizzle out in an incredibly short amount of time. Also even if an object with infinite density somehow had volume, would it require infinite energy to transfer sound, as it would behave as though it had an infinite number of particals within it? I also wonder if infinite density is not needed to travel faster than light, and tightly packed subatmoic particals with no space between them like those in nuetron stars work? Could a chain of neutrons that have somehow been bonded indestructibly make an infinitely fast compression wave? Or would the energy required to make a detectable disturbance simply warp space time so much that it just gives the space-time the wire occupies infinite curvature and just forms a singularity?

Well I'm wrapping my speculations up here cause my thumbs are about to fall off. Please correct or add to any of my thoughts as I have no physics background other than the internet and high school science classes. Also feel free to suggest theories or contribute any supportive or contradictory physics knowlede.

If you're interested: the video displaying how it would look to travel to Andromeda at the speed of light is actually wrong.  As you approach the speed of light, the distance from your perception to your destination is decreased and you would reach Andromeda instantly. The concept of time doesn't even really apply in the same way to would-be particles traveling at the speed of light (which is not possible). However an observer on earth would see a strongly red-shifted image of you taking years to reach the other galaxy.

9:38 Actually, this "lagging effect" is exactly how the speed of light was measured for the first time. The scientists put two wheels with a notch into a way of a pulsating light source, synchronized the pulses with an exact position of the notch and then projected the resulting image onto a screen. When the wheels were turning slowly, the notch on the screen was matching the notches at the wheels but as they rotated the wheels faster and faster, the image of the notch on the screen started to shrink. They increased the speed to the point where the image of the notch disappeared, took note of the speed of the wheels and then used this speed and a couple of other metrics (diameter of the wheels, distance between the wheels) to get the speed of light.

0:32 Not just digital cameras. Almost all old television cameras suffered from the same effect because the way how the signal was captured was exactly equivalent to the "rolling shutter" you talk about. The only difference is that these old cameras were scanning the image 50/60 times per second while modern digital cameras do so only about 20 times per second. This makes the resulting distortion quite different.

Hey, Vsauce! Michael Here.

I am distorted. The pixels you are watching have been timed displaced. They've been mapped onto a gradient and the darker the region they're mapped to, the further behind they lag. The effect is really fun but it's certainly not realistic.
Or is it?
* https://youtu.be/TN25ghkfgQA?t=2 *

Many, many popular digital cameras suffer from lag induced distortion, like what you just saw, though much, much more subtle. Usually completely unnoticeable. It's called a rolling shutter.

Instead of snapping a full exposure at once they quickly scan strips of each frame. It's usually undetectable. But when the subject changes faster than the camera scans, you get the famous geloey wobbly rolling
shutter effect. Really fast things, like vibrating guitar strings and
airplane propellers, are famous victims, but people can be too.
Luke Mandel submitted this photo to Boing Boing. His camera scans left to
right and, in this instance, managed to capture a blink, eyes closed when the scan began and then open in the
reflection scanned a fraction of a second later.

But the rolling shutter effect is not just a neat curiosity. It represents a fundamental and inescapable distortion that affects everything we see. Rolling shutter or not. First things first, let's talk about distortions.

A hallucination is a distortion of reality when there is no apparent stimulus. If you are merely misinterpreting an actual stimulus, that is an illusion. But some distortions occur before our sense organs and minds get in the way. They are called optical phenomena. They are not the result of sensation or perception gone wrong. Instead, optical phenomena are distortions
caused by the mere properties of light and matter in and of themselves.

If you look up at the sky and see a giant vivid drinking gourd, two-dimensional connect-the-dots
Big Dipper, you are seeing an illusion. It's an illusion because those dots merely appear to be on the same plane, like
holes poked in the dark roof of the sky. In reality, those dots are stars lightyears apart from one another in three dimensions.
As Celestron's brilliant free real-time 3D visualization of space shows, from different perspectives, besides our own, they look a lot less like a dipper or plough. In fact, all constellations and asterisms are geocentric illusions. From a wider perspective their outlines point inward, to the single lowly point in space that gave them their names.

But you can't blame us. I mean, Earth is the only perspective any human has ever had. And even Voyager 1, the most distant man-made object, is still not even close to being far
enough away for the constellations to look even remotely different than they do here on Earth. It's also not our fault, our eyes' and brains' fault, that distant, distant stars weren't included in our early cosmic connect-the-dot game. Sure, our eyesight could be better, but optical phenomena are also to blame. If it weren't for red shifting and the inverse square law and light extinction, distant things could be seen in all their glory. The night sky would look phenomenal. Many structures up there are huge. They're just too dim for their hugeness to be appreciated.
When we see Hubble Telescope images of distant objects, like the Helix Nebula, it's easy to think that, without a telescope to zoom in, the object must just be a tiny point in the sky. But in reality, even though the Helix Nebula is 700 light years away, it's 3 lightyears across. If we could make the Helix Nebula less dim, if our eyes could take a really long exposure of it, we would see the Helix Nebula as it really is - nearly 70% the apparent diameter of our Moon. This is a serious picture. That is how large the Helix Nebula would appear in the night sky from Earth if it just wasn't so dim. Our Moon is tiny in the sky, by the way. It's easy to think of the moon as this huge baseball-sized thing up there in the sky, but that's an illusion.

Try this the next time you see the Moon. Grab a sheet of notebook paper and you will notice that the angular
diameter of the Moon is the same size as a hole punched in a sheet of notebook paper held in arms-length away. Seriously, try it sometime. It shows just how cute and tiny our little moon is.
The Orion Nebula would appear even larger, if we saw all of its light. And the Andromeda Galaxy? Just a smudge in the sky to our eyes. But if our eyes were better at collecting dim light, we would see Andromeda's true extent in our sky. Of course, our night sky doesn't look like that. Distant objects are dimmer, that's a bummer.

But light still wins when it comes to speed. Light travels at the fastest speed. In fact, in a vacuum, light travels 300,000 kilometres a second. That's fast. But not really. I mean, not compared to how far apart things are in the universe. Sydney, Australia is 1/14th of a light second away from London. But the Andromeda Galaxy is 2,500,000 light years away from London. To put that in perspective let's take a light speed journey from London to Sydney. It would look like this... Ready? Three, two, one, go! Nice! Alright, alright.

Here's the Andromeda Galaxy. Okay, now, relativistic effects aside, let's take a look at what it would look like to travel toward the Andromeda Galaxy at the speed of light. Are you ready? Alright. Three, two, one, go! Yeah. I mean, seriously, it's pretty lame. Even at the speed of light, the fastest speed possible, a year from now we won't even be a millionth of the way there.

That's how far away Andromeda is. It's almost sad in a way. But this brings us back to the rolling shutter effect. The Andromeda Galaxy is huge. It's more than a hundred thousand light years across and our view of it is tilted. Which means that, on the plane we view it in, light from the back represents what Andromeda looked like thousands and thousands of years before what light from the front represents.Changes in its appearance reach us sooner from the front than from the back. Andromeda is rotating, spinning at hundreds of kilometers per second in some places. Now, a lag between light coming from near and far points on a spinning object, results in a skewed image. The rolling shutter effect on a cosmic scale applied to, say, a chessboard, seeing the front ahead of the back is pretty trippy and dramatic.

So, does that mean we see wobbly, funhouse mirror, rolling shutter effect versions of Andromeda and other distant galaxies? Well, technically yeah, but the distortion is negligible. It may as well be ignored. Why? Well, the speeds used in these visualizations are not to scale. On average, yes, matter within galaxies orbits the galactic center at hundreds
of kilometers per second but galaxies are so huge it takes them hundreds of millions of years to complete just one rotation. In other words, the lag between light reaching you from near and far points on a galaxy, is nothing compared to how much time it takes matter in the galaxy to travel that same distance.

In the case of Andromeda, if you insisted on seeing Andromeda as it really is, that is, corrected for any lag caused by the fact that the speed of light is finite, the most extreme points on the Galaxy would only need to be adjusted by about a 10,000th of the width of any image. In this case, less than a pixel. So, it's not a big deal. But it's not a nothing deal. It's real. In fact, everything we look at is, in some way, distorted by the fact that the speed of light is finite. Your own feet are about 5 to 6 light nano seconds away from your eyes, which means when you look at your feet you are seeing where they were 5 to 6 nano seconds ago. 5 to 6 nanoseconds in the past.

Of course, a delay that brief is pretty much undetectable but it is calculate-able. If it makes you feel a little sad to know that even with the sharpest mind or the best instruments, appearances still depend on where you are. That optical phenomena insure appearances are always relative(?) Don't feel bad. We call the people closest to us our relatives.

We're really just a family, a big family of reference frames that, like a family, don't always agree but do have plenty of cool things to look at.

I'd like to thank my editor, Guy, for help with the rolling shutter effect in this video. And I'd like to thank you, because, as always thanks for reading.

Fun fact about the Rolling Shutter effect, it predominantly affects cameras that are built poorly. Canon, Nikon, and to some extent Sony all suffer from this problem, not only because their sensors are large and dense, but also because the bus between their sensor and their image processor.

For the uninitiated, a BUS, in computing terms, is nothing more than the thing between two components that pushes data between the two components. Some components will have multiple busses to transmit data in parallel(though that rarely works all that well, and in most cases, isn't used anymore), some will have multiple busses used to transmit to and from different parts of the same component, but at the end of the day, the best way to think about it is that it's the connection between two things. Not quite as rudimentary as just being a cable, a bus is an actual controller of data moving from point A to point B, for the most part. In fact, you interact with one specific type of one every day, I'm willing to bet. A bus that's universal, and passes data effectively in a single line, one bit at a time, or in a Serial pattern. A Universal, Serial bus. Or, for short, USB.

Now that we have a firm understanding of the bus between components, we have to take a closer look at the internals of your average digital camera. Typically, your sensor will be pulling data from the incoming light the whole time it is exposed, but your image processor will only be receiving the data it is given by the bus. Because it's a bit-by-bit transfer, if the bus is too slow, or it runs into an issue wherein the image processor does not have the available bandwidth to pull and push data fast enough, we can start to run into issues. Now, you can see this happening every day on your smartphone, or your computer, if you try to watch a streaming video, but your connection is too slow. For streaming video, you'll run into buffering issues, which might set you behind a few seconds at a time, but when you're processing realtime data, and you can't set things behind anymore, that gets... trickier.

Because capturing a moment as it happens is the core principal behind any digital camera worth its salt, the image sensor won't often bother to buffer the data(Some models do, but they're often substandard for reasons I'll get into later), and will simply transfer whatever it can, whenever it can, at the request of the image processor. So if the bus is too slow, or the processor hits peaks in its bandwidth of transfer speed, which in most cases is just fine handling a pretty broad amount of data at once unless conditions become less than ideal(again, more on that later), you can start to see distortion, and in some cases, even banding.

Let's start on that data buffering problem. Some cheaper cameras, usually Smartphone cameras, get around this problem by just... Turning down the data throughput. This variation of bit rate, appropriately referred to as Variable Bitrate, is, while functionally usable, inconsistent, and can result in some messy encoding issues, up to and including sound desync problems as re-encoding of the footage fails to take into account the timing between the sound and video.

But what about those ideal conditions? Processors of any kind work best when they're in their ideal thermal range, a range of temperatures wherein a processor won't start throwing errors, or running less and less efficiently in terms of thermal waste. Now you might think that an ASIC, or Application Specific Integrated Circuit, like you'd find in a calculator or a camera, wouldn't have trouble overheating, but that's where you'd be wrong. Camera processors have to take in all of the data from the sensor, encode it on the fly, and store it on whatever the storage media happens to be, typically an SD card. In processing terms, that's a lot of work. They also have to take all that data from the sensor, in real time, and push it to whatever viewscreens you have set up, whether it be the camera's built in screen, or an external monitor, and overlay any necessary information on top of that. They're busy little processors, but shouldn't they know how not to overheat? Wouldn't that be something that's tested thoroughly? Well, not exactly.

See, Camera manufacturers are in the business of making Cameras. They're not necessarily in the business of making Computers, and while some of the engineering challenges can be similar, if you don't have specialists in processor design that have a lengthy understanding of each new process node and how it functionally differs from the ones that came before it, you can run into issues wherein a processor is designed, manufactured, and sold, but with a lot more flaws. In fact, Camera manufacturers can actually run into issues just based on the level of fault tolerance they allow for in their system processors, and will often accept bins (a reference to slight variations in speed and heat handling) that are along a much broader scale of acceptability than a manufacturer of something like a Desktop processor. When you buy a desktop, you can generally guarantee that two 3.0GHz processors, as labelled, from the same manufacturer, same part number, all that, should be functionally identical, but with the broader tolerances, two cameras can have totally different ideal processing speeds, which means that two cameras can generate very different heat profiles. But what does this mean for the quality of the data? Well, as processors heat up, they use more power, which can actually start to affect the camera's power budget, taking power from the sensor amplifier circuitry, the camera's built in screen, and even just running into not having enough power to run the processor itself at that rate. The result is a loss of exposure control, usually very slight, or banding appearing on the main screen, wherein you will see black bars start passing down the screen, or at the absolute worst, signal interruptions in the encoding process, wherein you will get video footage with stutters, stops, and in some cases, an absolute failure to properly encode the stream, resulting in a catastrophic loss of everything you've just recorded.

Most image processors shouldn't run into heat issues TOO often, but companies like Canon and Nikon still cling to image processors built on nodes prone to heat issues anyway, so that's an issue all on its own. But when you add in that slower bus, regardless of the processor's power, you're gonna run into problems. Companies like Panasonic get around this problem by not only incorporating a faster bus, but by also incorporating a processor that can better delineate tasks, and can handle encoding bitrates WELL beyond what other cameras can(with the GH4 model being able to handle up to a 200Mbps, which, while it creates HUGE files, results in video that is Amazing for editors and keying experts), but also by keeping the sensor relatively small.

At the end of the day, the issue of tearing, or the rolling shutter, is one not of just technology, but of a failure to use it properly. Things that are marketable get improved(i.e. "IT HAS MORE MEGAPIXELS!"), but like a megamall or a gigantic condominium tower, if the infrastructure isn't improved to handle the increased flow, you're going to run into problems.

I wish to point out there never was any scientific measurement made of how fast light travels in vacuum. All measurements ever made were done on earth not further then 3 miles distance between source and target.
Nobody can can say with any specific precision how fast light is travelling anywhere, as we need to have perfectly synchronised time source, which we can proof at the time of measurement being made that it is still synchronised. There is a way to check, if it synchronised, but there is no way to know how much it would progress or drift between measurements of both sides. Therefore measuring such great speeds is beyond any human capabilities at the moment and will stay that way most probably forever, as there will be no safe way to ever prove that there was no drift between time-sources at the time of measurement and the was no drift of speed of data (time) transmission or light did not get any faster or slower on the way.
technically measurement of speed of light is impossible with any reasonable accuracy.
I can for instance say that when I would hop on bus it is moving faster then 0mph and slower then 30mph, but without any precise measurement of time and environment through which bus is moving I cannot estimate bus speed with any better accuracy. Same goes to speed of light.
P.S. I can calculate pretty close average speed of bus, but I would not be able to calculate exact average speed of bus, unless I would measure distance it travels, while it travels and exact time when it travels.

I would like to add that we are only seeing the light 'shadow' of Andromeda anyway. It's apparent position isn't its actual position. In the time the light has traveled from the galaxy to our eyes, the galaxy has since traveled through space also.
Most of the stars you see in the sky aren't actually there. You see the light at the time it illumined from the star. In the time it took that light to travel across space to reach your eye, the star has since shifted position.

Actually, the light speed trip to Andromeda would look nothing like that. Special relativity tells us that once we accelerated to light speed the distance from us to Andromeda would be 0 due to length contraction, and the time that passed for us would be 0 thanks to time dilation. So we'd arrive instantly. Also, all light emitted from Andromeda would be blue shifted past visible light, x-ray, gamma rays, etc. If you had said we traveled at 0.9c and stopped to check our progress after 1 year, this picture would be reasonably accurate.

I have a question. Actually a series of related question ...
Why does light move? We're awash in the entire electromagnetic spectrum of which visible light is just a small portion. And that's cool because if light didn't move it wouldn't stimulate our optic nerve. And if light didn't move we wouldn't see anything unless we constantly moved forward into static light.
But ... our current understanding is that light, or I should say photons which when we get enough of them together we call light, have no mass.
So, what compels an object with no mass, in this case light, to move? And what sustains it's movement?
 Why is light, along with the rest of the electromagnetic spectrum, visible from billions of light years away? What's the engine? Where does the energy come from?
Not the energy of light itself, but the energy that causes it to move?

You should not dismiss the relativistic effects when moving at fast speeds, because then you would get there faster due to length contraction. If you had a spacecraft capable of infinite 1G acceleration, you could travel the distance of 100M light years in 41,2 years. Now we just need a spacecraft that can generate 1G of acceleration for 41,2 years (a bit relaxed from the infinite, but still impossible with current tech). Notice that this is from the spacecrafts frame of reference, an observer on planet earth would still have to wait for a very very long time. A bit more than 100M years, I'm too lazy to calculate it :)  (my formula to calculate the time is this SQRT(4 * d / a) point my mistake if I made one, It should take into account that you want to come to a stop at the end and that the point of origin and target are not moving relative to eachother)

I wonder, what is the largest object that could be built?

I mean, there are huge ships, over a thousand feet long, that carry cargo or oil or whatever. But they're pretty small compared to the largest buildings which are pushing (maybe exceeded? dunno) a half mile in height and are probably thousands of times more massive than the ships.

Then there are things like dams that have much more mass to them than the buildings.

But all of those are here on the Earth. I wonder if (hopefully when) we start building large structures in space how large they could be?

The Halo game series comes to mind. There are space stations that are up to a few hundred miles in length. That's pretty massive.

But then there are the Halo rings which, if memory serves, are a few thousand kilometers in diameter and much longer in circumference.

And then there are shield worlds, which I guess would be about the diameter of the rings, but are actual spheres filled with matter.

And the there's the Ark, which I think is the largest object in the series. At the center it manufactures the Halo rings, but it extends out far beyond them. If I had to guess I'd say it's maybe the size of one of the gas giants in our solar system. Maybe Neptune or something, not Jupiter. Still, that's tens of thousands of kilometers across and must be beyond anything that could be constructed, right? 

But then there are plans for something called a Dyson sphere: a constructed sphere that completely surrounds a star, preferably in the 'goldilocks' zone to sustain life. That would be millions of kilometers across and surely require more matter than would be possible to obtain to construct it, right?

If the CPU in your computer runs at 3 GHz one clock cycle takes exactly 1/3 nanosecond. At the same time light travels at 29,98 centimeters per nanosecond. This means that if you are sitting 29,98 cm from your screen (approx. one foot) your CPU will be able to perform 3 arithmetic instructions (these only require a single clock cycle) and calculate "2014 - (42+9000)" from the time the photons leave your screen to the time they reach your eyes. In other words: What you see on your screen is so old that when it actually happened your CPU hadn't yet performed the 3 instructions it just finished ;-)

what blows my mind is that not only are you seeing your foot from the past, but you are feeling it from the past too.  Your nerves are sending feeling information slower than the light going to your eyes.  So you don't exactly know where you foot is by looking or feeling it....  creepy.  Obviously negligible delays but still.  Blows my mind.

Hey michael, can I point out an mistake in a part of your video?

When you show what it looks like when you travel to andromeda at the speed of light, the still image is incorrect (so is the journey from london to sydney for that matter). According to Einstein's relativity theory, due to time dilation, from the reference frame of the travelling object, when you travel at the speed of light you arrive instantaneously at your destination. This is only true if you are travelling at exactly the speed of light. From the outside observer's point of view, the traveller would be travelling at the speed of light, but the traveller's observation would be that he is travelling at infinite speed. Another effect is that the traveller would be quashed to zero length in the direction he is travelling.

- edit - OK, after watching a second time I realise you said "relativistic effects aside". You win :)

On another note, as posted by another person earlier, Neutron stars, and in particular magnetars, are a very interesting subject as their magnetic fields can reach a quadrillion Gauss. Can cause some nice effects on objects. Maybe you can do a Vsauce on that and related subjects?

My mind is blown by the concept that the angular diameter of the Andromeda galaxy is so much larger than the tiny smudge of light that's visible to the human eye from Earth's surface. Seeing it's full extend makes it's 2.5 M light-year distance seem not so far after all.

This raises a question: We see Andromeda as a tiny smudge because the light from its trillion stars is so dim that the spiral arms are invisible to us. However, a telescope sees it better because it has a larger light-collecting aperture than our eyes and can make a time exposure. Hubble sees it better yet because in addition to an ordinary telescope's advantages, it is also outside the bulk of Earth's light-scattering and -distorting atmosphere. But what does the Andromeda galaxy look like to an unaided human eye from space? Have any astronauts or cosmonauts ever described it? I'm sure it's better than our Earth-bound view, but does just being outside the atmosphere make up for its dimness enough that the spiral arms are visible, or does the space traveler just see a brighter tiny smudge of light?

Michael dear,
A very very very small part of your video's wrong. At 6:45 you say it would take many years for light to go from here to another galaxy "from a photon's perspective". This is WRONG. The exact time which takes for a photon to go from some place to another place "in its OWN reference frame" is ZERO. The time for a photon is the "proper time" and that time is any relative time divided by INFINITY, therefore it's ZERO.

The photons gathered and used to create these images of the Andromeda galaxy traveled for 2.5 million years through space (and eventually a camera lens), to hit a camera sensor. So what you are seeing when you look at these images is actually what the galaxy looked like 2.5 million years ago. ALSO, the core of the Andromeda galaxy can be seen on a dark, clear night using a simple pair of binoculars. :)

"If we could make the Helix Nebula less dim, we would see the Helix Nebula as it really is" No, we would see the Helix Nebula as it would be if it were less dim. That particular error - and everything in this video contending that perspective creates nothing more than illusion - comes from a materialist bias that perception, conception and consciousness in general are not "real" and that their effects should be ignored; a bias which real modern science (not the modern science of the 19th century which most people are still in love with) disagrees with. See quantum physics and wave function collapse. Or an easier example: a mirror (the presence of a particular reflection as opposed to a superposition of all potential reflections depends upon an observer) or a rainbow (the presence of a rainbow depends upon an observer)

just a correction, it's Global Shutter not Total Shutter. and many smartphones/digital camera today using CMOS sensor. CMOS usually using Rolling Shutter, that's why you will see jello effects/wobbly video or image. and CCD sensor is using Global Shutter. that's why any CCD cameras do not suffer any jello effects. because it's capture a whole full frame in one time. :D

Nothing ever touches. In order to get from here to there you cover half the distance.  But when you get to the halfway point there is still the distance from here to there. So, you cover half the distance. Still, the dilema is there is still that pesky distance and there is an infinite amount of halves. Even if we were to get close enough to "touch" something there is still an electromagnetic charge blocking the actual objects from touching, even at the most minute level. So, if nothing touches, how do we move our arms and legs and how can we transfer that kind of influence to objects, not connected to our body and brain? That's a fun place to explore for me :)

Actually the oscillation effects that happens with the guitar strings isn't caused by rolling shutter. It happens when the shutter speed of the camera is very high so it can capture the string with almost no motion blur. This effect can also be seen in a high speed photograph even if its taken with a film camera (which doesn't cause any rolling shutter effect).

I'm surprised that they didn't mention the time shift that affects moving objects. Anything moving at the speed of light does not experience time. So, while something may be 1 billion light years away, light leaving it hits your eyes at the exact same moment (according to it) that it left, although 1 billion years have gone by for us.

For all of you moaning and groaning about not being able to enjoy andromeda and the nebulae with your own eyes, you can see something just as beautiful here on earth. Just go to a dark sky area at night during the summer (since the brightest area is visible) and about 10:30pm or so you will be able to see the beautiful dust lanes and large scale structure of the milky way in the sky. Just look up milky way astrophotography. Better yet, watch some meteors streak through against a backdrop of the milky way. It's really the most beautiful natural thing I've seen in my life.  Also if you live around CA a great place for this is mono lake (around yosemite) which is the picture in my avatar.
